        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>psycnet.apa.org</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running. Additional information is available in this <a title='Third party browser plugins that block javascript' href='http://ds.tl/help-third-party-plugins' target='_blank'>support article</a>.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>
          To request an unblock, please fill out the form below and we will review it as soon as possible.
        </p>

 <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">

    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2603519/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495066533 (ipmc11)</div>

 <html lang="en">
                  <head>
                      <link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" media="screen, print" href="//fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans:300italic,400italic,600italic,700italic,800italic,400,300,600,700,800"/>
                      <meta charset="UTF-8"/>
                      <link rel="stylesheet" href="/assets/legacy_20150923T1420/files/legacy/css/legacy.css"/>
                      <link rel="icon" type="image/png" href="http://jstorstatic.global.ssl.fastly.net/sassafrassv1/images/favicon.ico"/>
                      <link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="http://jstorstatic.global.ssl.fastly.net/sassafrassv1/images/apple-touch-icon.png"/>

 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="iso-8859-1"?>
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN"
         "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>

						height: 60px;
					}
				}

			.logo { display: none; }
			.logo.mobile { display: table; }

				height: 60px;
			}

			}

        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>www.indiegogo.com</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running.         </ul>
        <p>
          To request an unblock, please fill out the form below and we will review it as soon as possible.
        </p>

                          <li class="has-dropdown"><a href="/action/showJournals" class="menu-heading" id="menu-global-browse">Browse</a>
                              <ul class="dropdown">
                                  <li><a href="/action/showJournals?browseType=title">by Title</a></li>
                                  <li><a href="/action/showJournals?browseType=publisherInstance">by Publisher</a></li>
                              </ul>
                          </li>
                          <li class="has-dropdown"><a href="/action/showRegistrationUpdate?myJstor=true" class="menu-heading"
                                                      id="menu-global-myjstor">MyJSTOR</a>
                              <ul class="dropdown">
                                  <li><a href="/action/showRegistrationUpdate?myJstor=true">My Profile</a></li>
                                  <li><a href="/action/showShelf">Shelf</a></li>
                                  <li><a href="/action/showSubscriptions">JPASS Downloads</a></li>
                                  <li><a href="/action/showPurchases">Purchase History</a></li>
                              </ul>
                          </li>
                          <li>
                              <a href="/action/showLogin"
                                 class="menu-heading" id="menu-global-getaccess">Get Access</a></li>
                      </ul>
                      </nav>
                      <div id="content" role="main" class="content row">
                      <div class="large-8 column maincontent column-max-width brandingStripe noGlobalSrch">

                          <h1>Access Check</h1>

                          <p>Our systems have detected unusual traffic activity from your network.
                             Please complete this Captcha to demonstrate that it's you making the requests and not a robot.
                             If you are having trouble seeing or completing this challenge,
                             <a href="https://support.jstor.org/hc/en-us/articles/115011068868-Troubleshooting-CAPTCHA-">this page</a>
                             may help.
                             If you continue to experience issues, you can
                             <a href="mailto:support@jstor.org">contact JSTOR Support</a>.</p>

                          <div id="CAPTCHA"></div>
                          <p>Block Reference: #9504aaa0-aec9-11e7-80bf-9f3dac7f8a2f</p>

                      </div>

					<img src="https://lareviewofbooks-org-cgwbfgl6lklqqj3f4t3.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/salon-1.jpg" width="100%" height="auto" />
				</div>
			</a>
		</div>
		<!-- end of the loop -->
	
		
		<!-- beginning of the loop -->
		<div class="grid-12 grid-centered">

	<section class="mobile-only">

<div id="content">
	<section class="header article standard" style="background: #762424;">
		<header class="article container">
			<div class="grid-9 grid-mobile-12">
				<!--p class="category red-text-color">PHOTOGRAPHER SPOTLIGHT</p-->
				<h1 class="article-title white-text">Beating Around the Bush: Annamarie Jagoses Orgasmology</h1>
				<p class="byline white-text">By <a href='/contributor/sand-avidar-walzer' title='Sand Avidar-Walzer'>Sand Avidar-Walzer</a></p>
			</div>
		</header>
	</section><!-- /section.hero -->
	<div class="container">
		<div class="row">
										<div class="grid-12">
				<!-- /6263889/v2_articls_top-->

						<article class="post-content grid-7 grid-mobile-12">
				<br/>
<div class="ssk-group ssk-count" style="display: inline;">

<br/><br/>
<script type="text/javascript">
	jQuery( window ).on("load", function() {

		    url: 'https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/beating-around-the-bush-annamarie-jagoses-orgasmology/',
		    text: 'Los Angeles Review of Books: Beating Around the Bush: Annamarie Jagoses Orgasmology',
		    twitter: {
		        url: 'https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/beating-around-the-bush-annamarie-jagoses-orgasmology/',
		        text: 'Los Angeles Review of Books: Beating Around the Bush: Annamarie Jagoses Orgasmology',
		        via: 'lareviewofbooks'

<div class="clear clearfix"></div>

				<br/>
				<p class="post-date">JUNE 26, 2013</p>
				<p>IN 1976, AT THE HEIGHT of his cultural influence in France, the philosopher Michel Foucault published one of the most famous books ever written on the history of sexuality, titled, aptly enough, <em>The History of Sexuality, Vol. I</em>. (The book was to be the first of a projected six-part series.) In Annamarie Jagose&rsquo;s <em>Orgasmology</em>, in which Foucault plays a small but starring role, she quotes David Halperin&rsquo;s remarks in his literally hagiographic <em>Saint Foucault</em> (1995) as typical of the rapturous reception the book received in queer circles: it was &ldquo;the text that, everyone now says, <em>you can&rsquo;t even begin to practice queer politics without reading</em>.&rdquo;</p>
<p><em>The History of Sexuality</em> was, at least in part, an attempt to explore the relationship between sexuality as <em>a kind of behavior</em> and sexuality as <em>an object of clinical diagnosis</em>. The book picks up in the same vaguely &ldquo;Victorian&rdquo; late-19th-century epos where <em>The History of Madness</em>, Foucault&rsquo;s dissertation and first critical success, left off: with the birth of a socio-clinical regime of observation and analysis whose work is to distinguish the normal from the pathological. <em>The History of Sexuality</em> was not so much a sequel to <em>The History of Madness</em> as a companion volume, asking different kinds of questions. Between the two books, the entire framework of Foucault&rsquo;s inquiry has shifted. The former closes with a negative claim: psychoanalysis <em>does not</em> truly &ldquo;liberate&rdquo; madness. The latter opens with what we might call a <em>positive</em> problem: psychoanalysis doesn&rsquo;t liberate, but it does <em>something</em>, apparently. What, then, does psychoanalysis do? Foucault&rsquo;s answer: it evaluates. It determines which sexual behaviors are normal enough to justify freedom, and which are pathological enough to demand carceral oppression. But it does not evaluate all by itself; it does so as part of an incredible machinery of regulation, a regulation which is <em>not the same as</em> the corporeal oppression of incarceration, from which psychoanalysis had helped psychiatry &ldquo;liberate&rdquo; the mad.</p>
<p>To make this point Foucault introduces, in <em>The History of Sexuality</em>, a new category: normativity. &ldquo;Normativity,&rdquo; a concept which both Jagose and the academic discourse known as &ldquo;queer theory&rdquo; draw on extensively, is a new way of controlling, of evaluating, of judging; a mechanism of repression that is not simply psychoanalytic, but which, together with psychoanalysis and a plethora of other discourses, forms a generalized but closely policed middle ground between the ideal, healthy citizen in society and physical incarceration of those deemed to have no place in society at all. Normativity, in this conceptual framework, is not a <em>thing</em>, but a way of adjudicating between an impossible ideal and its literal failure.</p>
<p><em>The History of Madness</em> ends at the close of the 19th century, with the rise of contemporary institutional psychiatry. In Foucault&rsquo;s narrative, psychiatric internment is always the dark shadow of psychoanalysis: <em>if your cockamamie talking doesn&rsquo;t do the trick, give &rsquo;em back to us and we&rsquo;ll sedate &rsquo;em</em>. For Foucault, Freud is complicit in the literal, corporeal oppression of the &ldquo;ill&rdquo;; psychoanalysis, a cog in the machinery of normativity, is a gatekeeper, drawing the line between illness and madness, and, implicitly, between freedom and incarceration. <em>The History of Madness</em> explores the ways in and through which those excluded from society were excluded and the ways in which their bodies were restrained; <em>The History of Sexuality</em> explores the ways in which a social order that has reintroduced the sick and the perverse into its own milieu undertakes to police these newly liberated subjects to make sure they don&rsquo;t slip up. An all-or-nothing regime of binary exclusion &mdash; you <em>are</em> mad or you <em>aren&rsquo;t</em> mad &mdash; is replaced with a rhizomatic network of regimentation &mdash; <em>what kind of problem do you have?</em> &ldquo;Normativity,&rdquo; as Foucault originally constructed the concept, is less a fascist dictator and more a parole officer-slash-social worker: <em>We know you want to</em>, it says,<em> and it&rsquo;s okay to have those thoughts. Just make sure you don&rsquo;t act on them</em>.</p>
<p>The best parts of Jagose&rsquo;s <em>Orgasmology</em> explore the same terrain as Foucault&rsquo;s later work. Like Foucault, Jagose explores the concepts, texts, and data generated by the &ldquo;scientific&rdquo; attempt to map notions of normativity onto actual bodies. But where Foucault studies the general structural conditions which make this project possible, Jagose narrows in on a single phenomenon: the orgasm. Jagose&rsquo;s archive is the material generated in elaborating the relationship between the event of orgasm and an ideal state of mental and physical normativity.<em> </em>&ldquo;Take Marie Bonaparte, for example,&rdquo; Jagose writes:</p>
<blockquote>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">who was analyzed by Sigmund Freud in the 1920s and later made influential contributions to psychoanalytic theorizations of the acquisition of femininity. Bonaparte&rsquo;s lifelong pursuit &mdash; both theoretical and applied &mdash; of vaginal orgasm included repeated and unsuccessful surgical modification of her own genitals and continues to elicit &ldquo;amused and dismissive responses from many historians and scholars of psychoanalysis.&rdquo; Wilhelm Reich [&hellip;] [did] little better [given his] insistence on the supremacy of the libido above all other psychoanalytic concepts, his belief that full genital orgasm was the only guarantee of psychic health.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>In the book&rsquo;s fascinating third chapter, Jagose describes the place of orgasm in the &ldquo;sad and cruel flourishings of mid 20th- century behaviorist programs intended to reorient errant male erotic interests towards objects and practices deemed normal.&rdquo; This was the period in the 1960s especially during which psychiatry and behavioral psychology colluded to quantify the orgasm as the marker for heterosexual normativity. Jagose aims &ldquo;to trace across a set of case studies the uses to which orgasm is put in clinical practice designed to increase the incidence of erotic behavior deemed normal.&rdquo; This approach allows her to deal not only with psychoanalysis, but also with other 20th-century sciences such as clinical behaviorism. Clinical behaviorism, as Jagose describes it, &ldquo;understood itself &hellip; as an applied science that drew on behaviorist learning principles in order to design treatment protocols intended to modify undesirable behavior.&rdquo; The tricky part, for Jagose, is the concept of &ldquo;applied science.&rdquo; The very nature of the scientific paradigm in place in these trials demands a single set of operant principles which can be used to modify any kind of &ldquo;undesirable behavior,&rdquo; and, indeed, the clinical practices aimed to &ldquo;cure&rdquo; homosexual behavior &mdash; a methodology known as aversion therapy &mdash; were borrowed more or less intact from the treatment of alcoholism. &ldquo;Experimental techniques specifically developed in relation to one behavioral demographic were applied, often by the same clinicians, to treatments designed to address very different behaviors,&rdquo; Jagose writes. Without detracting from the ethical horror of the treatment, Jagose dryly captures the Groucho-Marxian dialectic of theory and practice which bolstered this behavioral science: &ldquo;James copies the treatment format faithfully, introducing only a couple of slight variations.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The diversity of the archival material covered in <em>Orgasmology</em> is the book&rsquo;s greatest strength. Jagose&rsquo;s method is an intricate meshwork of discourses, unified by her focus on the same elusive object. This is the method of inquiry that <em>Orgasmology</em> shares with <em>The History of Sexuality</em>. The complex question Jagose asks throughout the book &mdash; the <em>genealogical</em> question &mdash; is: how do we describe the mechanisms by which the clinical gaze distinguishes the normal from the pathological? In building her genealogy, Jagose is consistently attentive to the ways in which bodies and our knowledge of them are located not within the logic of normalcy and perversion, but at the very discursive junction where the work of defining normativity takes place. By attending to the ways in which various cultural discourses understand the relation between normativity and the orgasm (examples range from fist-fucking, queer theory&rsquo;s perpetual problem child, to Masters &amp; Johnson), Jagose shows how a single object of inquiry is attributed different values in different contexts. Even more importantly, she shows us that the mechanisms and methodologies by which we think we &ldquo;objectively&rdquo; understand the value of a phenomenon like the orgasm are themselves caught up in the networks of value that allow us to identify it in the first place.</p>
<p>To illustrate this point, Jagose provides the wonderful example of simultaneous orgasm. Widely espoused as the<em> </em>normative marital condition <em>par excellence</em> in the first half of the 20th century, Jagose describes how, as the concept of &ldquo;marital health&rdquo; was replaced by &ldquo;sexual health&rdquo; in professional medical discourse, simultaneous orgasm goes from being considered an ideal to being considered idealistic. The approximately comparative approach shows convincingly that the methodology of those evaluations has impacted the interpretation, citation, and cultural dissemination of the results themselves. <em>Orgasmology</em> is &ldquo;a loosely chronological series of case studies,&rdquo; each looking at a particular kind of &ldquo;data.&rdquo; Following Foucault, Jagose explores the supposedly &ldquo;objective&rdquo; study of a phenomenon like the orgasm as part of a larger process of social and corporeal regimentation. She observes that the same nominally stable phenomenon acquires greatly differing implications and meanings in relation to different cogs of the same regimenting machine. How, Jagose asks, is the orgasm evaluated by psychoanalysis? By behavioral psychology? By the 20th-century marriage manual? By <em>Shortbus</em>, a 21st-century film about a particular cluster of urban sexualities? (The film&rsquo;s unusual combinations of sexual identities, Jagose suggests, make modern sex visible &ldquo;as less a bind than a bond, less an impasse than a way of cohabiting.&rdquo;) And how is the orgasm evaluated by queer theory?</p>
<p>This last question is the thorniest of the many that Jagose pursues in <em>Orgasmology</em>. Her book<em> </em>begins and ends with references to queer theorists like Bersani, Berlant, and Butler along with Foucault, Michael Warner and, well, the rest of the usual suspects. The book&rsquo;s cover blurbs (from David Halperin and Heather Love), not to mention the black band on the back announcing &#8220;Queer Theory/Feminist Theory/Sex,&#8221; all suggest a self-conscious positioning within the field of queer theory, and Jagose clearly sees her study as in some way aligned with queer theory&rsquo;s objectives. &ldquo;To ask what queer theory teaches us about orgasm,&rdquo; she writes, is &ldquo;to offer up, by way of a provocation, the idea that queer theory and orgasm might be co-relevant, might usefully extend each other&rsquo;s expected reach.&rdquo;</p>
<p>Jagose defines queer theory as &ldquo;those posthumanist and anti-identitarian critical approaches that are energized by thinking against the practices, temporalities, and modes of being through which sexuality has been normatively thought.&rdquo; But this posthumanist and anti-identitarian critical approach, she goes on to note, has &ldquo;had next to nothing to say of orgasm.&rdquo; &ldquo;I say next to nothing rather than plain nothing,&rdquo; she adds, &ldquo;since, reading between the lines, it is possible to detect a whiff of the queer theoretical dismissal of orgasm, so subtextual and sotto voce I hesitate to call it a strand, in which orgasm gets aligned with the normal, against which the queer defines itself.&rdquo;</p>
<p>The difference between queer theory&rsquo;s inquiry and Jagose&rsquo;s is a subtle but crucial one. The history of queer theory has recently been traced by Janet Halleys&rsquo; <em>Split Decisions: How And Why to Take a Break From Feminism</em> (2008) and Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick&rsquo;s posthumous <em>The Weather In Proust</em> (2011), and Jagose&rsquo;s hesitation to embrace queer theory whole-heartedly lies, like that of Halley and Sedgwick, in its emphasis on the function of &ldquo;liberation&rdquo; in the movement between carceral oppression and clinical normativity. Foucault&rsquo;s <em>History of Sexuality</em> begins, in effect, by saying that talking about sexuality does not <em>fully</em> liberate sexuality, just as moving the mad out of the madhouse doesn&rsquo;t free them of pathology. The best works of queer theory &mdash; like Sedgwick&rsquo;s own <em>Epistemology of the Closet</em> (1990) &mdash; demonstrate the explanatory value in pursuing the implications of this analogy: that is, in exploring the ways that sexuality is not-yet liberated. But most queer theory, Jagose suggests, doesn&rsquo;t content itself with looking for the places where sexuality is not-yet liberated. It goes further, and makes the assumption that, once queer genealogy has discovered repression, then completing the task of liberation must be its next step: &ldquo;Too often, the assumed obviousness or self-evidence of the transformative political potential of subcultural sexual practices relies on the persistent belief that dissident sex pits itself against power in the name of liberation.&rdquo;</p>
<p>This is the concern voiced by Leo Bersani as early as his 1987 essay &ldquo;Is the Rectum a Grave?&rdquo; and echoed in Sedgwick&rsquo;s &ldquo;Paranoid Reading and Reparative Reading,&rdquo; her introduction to the 1995 edited volume <em>Novel Gazing: Queer Readings in Literature</em> (more recently anthologized in <em>Tendencies</em>, and tellingly cited in Jagose&rsquo;s own introduction). Jagose&rsquo;s reluctance to fully &ldquo;be&rdquo; a queer theorist or &ldquo;do&rdquo; queer theory is entirely understandable, given the nature of the questions she poses &mdash; queer theory is one way of looking at the problem of sexuality, and not the only or necessarily the best way. And she elaborates her resistance to queer theory in the same effective and carefully scholarly tone with which she elaborates the difficulties she identifies, for example, in the cognitive sciences.</p>
<p>But the casual reader &mdash; if we can still imagine such a thing for a critical monograph published by an academic publishing house notorious for the kind of high-theoretical queer imperative Jagose is resisting &mdash; wonders why Jagose spends so much time wrestling with queer theory when it is, so clearly, not the best or only way to understand the evaluation of the orgasm in the 20th century. Having identified the cognitive dissonance between the object of <em>Orgasmology</em> and the genealogical project of queer theory, why then does queer theory continue to be the privileged perspective for exploring the relation between queer theory, feminist theory, and sex, especially when it come to the orgasm, a phenomenon that can be read queer<em>ly</em> but is not, inherently, &ldquo;queer&rdquo;?</p>
<p>The difficulty in <em>Orgasmology</em>&rsquo;s treatment of queer theory is not its ambivalence; ambivalence can be a useful addition to any critical arsenal. Rather, the difficulty is conceptual, even dialectical: where her discussions of film, clinical behaviorism, and marriage manuals explain how their discourses work in their description of the orgasm, Jagose&rsquo;s engagement with queer theory emphasizes instead the ways in which queer theory <em>doesn&rsquo;t</em> work to describe the orgasm. Jagose echoes Sedgwick and Bersani in resisting an algorithm of direct proportion which makes liberation as an act of exposure coexenstive with unknowing as a condition of repression, and her criticisms of queer theory are careful and valid. But in the wake of similar criticism from so many of queer theory&rsquo;s leading voices, her reliance on it serves largely to reinforce the same spiral of negation, the same relentless focus on what <em>isn&rsquo;t</em> there and on what <em>fails</em> to happen. To put it more simply, it&rsquo;s not at all clear that queer theory is the best lens through which to evaluate queer theory&rsquo;s failures, or, for that matter, that queer theory&rsquo;s failures deserve pride of place in a book about 20th-century orgasms.</p>
<p>This is not to deny the queerness of the project itself. &ldquo;Willful cognitive dissonance&rdquo; is Jagose&rsquo;s description of her book&rsquo;s relation to its eye-catching cover, but could equally describe the very queerness of the theoretical tool that <em>Orgasmology</em> offers the reader: its own relentless curiosity, its willingness and even insistence on sliding in unexpected directions and showing us unexpected relations. Before we can find a new way of coming together, we sometimes have to beat around the bush for a while. That&rsquo;s the best of the many lessons <em>Orgasmology</em> has to offer.</p>
<p>Jagose offers a fascinating tour of the orgasm in the 20th-century, and queer theory isn&rsquo;t the only kid on the tourbus by any means. Halperin&rsquo;s back cover blurb for <em>Orgasmology</em> is as enthusiastic as his hagiographic reception of Foucault: &ldquo;Just when they told you queer theory was dead, along comes a book that shows, yet again, what all the excitement was &mdash; and is about [&hellip;] You finish this book feeling ten times smarter than when you started it.&rdquo; That last part is true, and Jagose&rsquo;s book is well worth the time. But one can&rsquo;t help but wonder whether the queerest thing <em>Orgasmology</em> could do would be not to say anything for, or to, &ldquo;queer theory&rdquo; at all. &nbsp;</p>
<p style="text-align: center;">&curren;</p>
<p><a href="lareviewofbooks.org/author.php?cid=1042"><em>Sand Avidar-Walzer lives in New York, where he is completing a dissertation on sexuality and ethics.</em></a></p>
				<br/>

        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>www.apa.org</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running.         </ul>
        <p>

                    <section id="section-content" class="section section-content">
  <div id="zone-content-wrapper" class="zone-wrapper zone-content-wrapper clearfix">  
  <div id="zone-content" class="zone zone-content clearfix container-12">    

    
    <div id="region-content-wrapper" class="clearfix">

                          
             
        <div class="grid-12 region region-content" id="region-content">
  <div class="region-inner region-content-inner">
    <a id="main-content"></a>
                        <div class="block block-system block-main block-system-main odd block-without-title odd block-without-title" id="block-system-main" data-omega-region="region-content" data-omega-index="1">
  <div class="block-inner clearfix">
                
    <div class="content clearfix">
      <article about="/error/page-not-found" typeof="sioc:Item foaf:Document" class="node node-system-page node-promoted node-published node-not-sticky author-qw-administrator odd clearfix" id="node-system-page-297">
        <span property="dc:title" content="Page Not Found" class="rdf-meta element-hidden"></span>  
  <div class="content clearfix">
    <div class="field field-name-field-image field-type-image field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><img typeof="foaf:Image" src="http://www.queensu.ca/sites/default/files/boohoo404.jpg" width="501" height="297" alt="Boo Hoo!" title="Boo Hoo!" /></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even" property="content:encoded"><p style="font-size: 40px;">Boo Hoo!</p>

<p>Oh no! The page you're looking for cannot be found or the name may have changed.</p>

<p>You can try to:</p>

<ul><li><a href="/search/pages">Search for the correct page</a></li>
	<li>Look for your topic on the <a href="/a-to-z">A-Z page</a></li>
	<li><a href="mailto:web@queensu.ca?subject=Problem%20with%20Queen's%20website">Contact the Queen's web team</a> for help</li>
</ul><p><em><a href="http://www.queensu.ca/encyclopedia/b/boo-hoo-bear">Who is Boo Hoo the Bear?</a></em></p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  <div class="clearfix">
          <nav class="links node-links clearfix"></nav>
    
      </div>
</article>    </div>
  </div>
</div>      </div>
</div>      
    </div>
      
 </div>
</div>

  <h1 class="img_logo"><a href="/pmc/" class="pmc_logo offscreen">PMC</a></h1>

                        <div class="content">

                            <div class="container">
    <div id="maincontent" class="twelve_col col">
        <div class="col1">
            <div>
  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1458143/pdf/immunology00248-0075.pdf</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495233205 (ipmc21)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:18:57</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC1458143%2Fpdf%2Fimmunology00248-0075.pdf%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495233205%20(ipmc21)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A18%3A57">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>
  </div>
</div>

	<li id="menu-item-466" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-menu-item page_item page-item-73 current_page_item"><a href="http://www.onearchives.org/about/history/">History</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-2514" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a href="http://www.onearchives.org/about/staff/">Staff</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-463" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a href="http://www.onearchives.org/about/board/">Board of Directors</a></li>

<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-5619" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page"><a href="http://www.onearchives.org/donate/2017-matching-gift-challenge/">2017 Matching Gift Challenge</a></li>

		<div id="content_inner">
			
			<div id="main">
				<div id="main_inner">
					
	
	
		<div id="post-73" class="post-73 page type-page status-publish hentry">
	
						
			<div class="entry">
				<h1><strong>History</strong></h1>
<p>Throughout his lifetime, Jim Kepner obsessively collected material related to LGBTQ topics, issues, and individuals. Kepner began his collection in 1942 with the purchase of Radclyffe Halls book <em>The Well of Loneliness</em>. After moving to Los Angeles, Kepner attended his first meeting of the Mattachine Society, an early homophile organization founded in 1951.</p>
<p>Later that year, several members of the Mattachine, including educator and activist W. Dorr Legg, met to discuss creating a magazine for homosexuals. In November 1952 they formed ONE Inc. and in January 1953 published the first issue of <em>ONE Magazine</em>, which would become the first widely distributed publication for homosexuals in the United States. The magazine featured articles, editorials, short stories, book reviews, and letters to the editor.</p>
<p>Kepner, A frequent contributor to <em>ONE Magazine</em>, along with Legg and Dr. Thomas M. Merritt, went on to found the ONE Institute, the educational arm of ONE Inc. that conducted seminars and published a journal. While <em>ONE Magazine</em> ceased publication in 1967, under Leggs guidance the Institute continued to advocate and educate, eventually issuing advanced degrees in Homophile Studies.</p>
<p>In 1971, Kepner named his collection, then housed in his rented Hollywood apartment, the Western Gay Archives. His archives would later move to a storefront space in Hollywood, becoming the National Gay Archives, and later, the International Gay &amp; Lesbian Archives, to reflect the growing scope of the collections.</p>
<p>In 1994, Kepners archives merged with the ONE Institute, and in 2000 moved to its current location provided by the University of Southern California. The archives would later be renamed ONE National Gay &amp; Lesbian Archives. In October 2010, the collections at ONE Archives became a part of the USC Libraries system. Today, ONE Archives is the oldest continuing LGBTQ organization in the United States and the largest repository of LGBTQ materials in the world.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h1><strong>Timeline</strong></h1>
<p><em> October 1952</em><br />
The idea of a magazine for homosexuals is first discussed in a Mattachine meeting.</p>
<p><em>November 1952</em><br />
ONE Inc. is founded.</p>
<p><em>January 1953</em><br />
The first issue of <em>ONE Magazine</em> is published.<br />
<em><br />
August/September 1953</em><br />
The Los Angeles postal authorities seize the August edition of <em>ONE Magazine</em>. The issue, which bore the title Homosexual Marriage? on the cover, is released three weeks later without explanation.</p>
<p><em>November 1953</em><br />
ONE Inc. opens an office in downtown Los Angeles at <a title="232 South Hill Street" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=232+S+Hill+St,+Los+Angeles,+CA&amp;hl=en&amp;sll=34.031077,-118.281574&amp;sspn=0.011932,0.02517&amp;oq=232+South+Hill+Street&amp;gl=us&amp;hnear=232+S+Hill+St,+Los+Angeles,+California+90013&amp;t=m&amp;z=16" target="_blank">232 South Hill Street</a>.</p>
<p><em>1954</em><br />
The Los Angeles postal authorities seize the October issues of <em>ONE Magazine</em> on charges of obscenity.</p>
<p><em>1956</em><br />
The ONE Institute for Homophile Studies opens.</p>
<p><em>January 13, 1958</em><br />
After four years of litigation, the Supreme Court declares <em>ONE Magazine</em> is not in violation of obscenity laws.<br />
<em><br />
1962</em><br />
ONE Inc. moves to <a title="2256 Venice Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA " href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=2256+Venice+Boulevard,+Los+Angeles,+CA&amp;hl=en&amp;ll=34.043468,-118.30797&amp;spn=0.01193,0.02517&amp;sll=34.043503,-118.30797&amp;sspn=0.01193,0.02517&amp;oq=2256+Venice+Boulevard,+Los+A&amp;gl=us&amp;hnear=2256+Venice+Blvd,+Los+Angeles,+California+90006&amp;t=m&amp;z=16">2256 Venice Boulevard</a>.<br />
<em><br />
1967</em><br />
<em>ONE Magazine </em>ceases publication.</p>
<p><em>1975</em><br />
Jim Kepners personal archive is named the Western Gay Archives.</p>
<p><em>1979</em><br />
The Western Gay Archives is renamed the National Gay Archives: Natalie Barney/Edward Carpenter Library and moves to <a title="1654 North Hudson Avenue, Los Angeles, CA" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=1654+North+Hudson+Avenue,+Los+Angeles,+CA&amp;hl=en&amp;ll=34.098017,-118.331552&amp;spn=0.011923,0.02517&amp;sll=34.087087,-118.332027&amp;sspn=0.011995,0.02517&amp;gl=us&amp;hnear=1654+N+Hudson+Ave,+Los+Angeles,+California+90028&amp;t=m&amp;z=16" target="_blank">1654 North Hudson Avenue</a> in Hollywood.</p>
<p><em>August 1981</em><br />
ONE Institute becomes the first institution of higher learning in the United States to offer masters and doctoral degrees in Homophile Studies.</p>
<p><em>1983</em><br />
ONE Inc. moves into the Milbank Estate at <a title="3340 Country Club Drive, Los Angeles, CA" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=3340+Country+Club+Drive,+Los+Angeles,+CA&amp;hl=en&amp;sll=34.098017,-118.331552&amp;sspn=0.011923,0.02517&amp;gl=us&amp;hnear=3340+Country+Club+Dr,+Los+Angeles,+California+90019&amp;t=m&amp;z=16" target="_blank">3340 Country Club Drive</a> purchased by philanthropist Reed Erickson. Soon after, for reasons uncertain, Erickson seeks to have ONE removed from the estate.<br />
<em><br />
1984</em><br />
The National Gay Archives is renamed the International Gay &amp; Lesbian Archives (IGLA).</p>
<p><em>1988</em><br />
IGLA moves to a space owned by the City of West Hollywood at <a title="626 North Robertson Boulevard, West Hollywood, CA" href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=626+N+Robertson+Blvd,+West+Hollywood,+CA&amp;hl=en&amp;sll=34.049599,-118.315749&amp;sspn=0.01193,0.02517&amp;oq=626+North+Robertson+Boulevard,+&amp;gl=us&amp;hnear=626+N+Robertson+Blvd,+West+Hollywood,+California+90069&amp;t=m&amp;z=16" target="_blank">626 North Robertson Boulevard</a> (the current location of the ONE Archives Gallery &amp; Museum).</p>
<p><em>1994</em><br />
W. Dorr Legg dies.</p>
<p>ONE Inc. merges with the IGLA and becomes primarily an LGBTQ archive; the organization refers to itself as ONE Institute and ONE Institute/IGLA.</p>
<p><em>1997</em><br />
Jim Kepner dies.</p>
<p><em>2000</em><br />
ONE Institute/IGLA moves to its current location at <a title="909 West Adams Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA " href="http://maps.google.com/maps?q=909+W+Adams+Blvd,+Los+Angeles,+CA&amp;hl=en&amp;sll=34.081747,-118.385427&amp;sspn=0.011925,0.02517&amp;oq=909+West+Adams+Boulevard&amp;gl=us&amp;hnear=909+W+Adams+Blvd,+Los+Angeles,+California+90007&amp;t=m&amp;z=16" target="_blank">909 West Adams Boulevard</a> provided by USC.</p>
<p><em>2004</em><br />
The organization is renamed ONE National Gay &amp; Lesbian Archives.</p>
<p><em>October 2010</em><br />
The collections at ONE Archives become a part of the USC Libraries.</p>
<p><em>2014</em><br />
The organization is renamed ONE Archives Foundation.</p>
				
				<div class="clearboth"></div>
				
												
				</div><!-- .entry -->
							
			
		</div><!-- #post-## -->

                      <nav id="nav-global" role="navigation">
                      <ul class="inline-list menu menu-global">

                                  <li><a href="/action/showJournals?browseType=title">by Title</a></li>

                      </nav>
                      <div id="content" role="main" class="content row">
                      <div class="large-8 column maincontent column-max-width brandingStripe noGlobalSrch">

                          <h1>Access Check</h1>

                          <p>Our systems have detected unusual traffic activity from your network.
                             Please complete this Captcha to demonstrate that it's you making the requests and not a robot.
                             If you are having trouble seeing or completing this challenge,
                             <a href="https://support.jstor.org/hc/en-us/articles/115011068868-Troubleshooting-CAPTCHA-">this page</a>
                             may help.
                             If you continue to experience issues, you can
                             <a href="mailto:support@jstor.org">contact JSTOR Support</a>.</p>

                          <div id="CAPTCHA"></div>
                          <p>Block Reference: #d5555b90-aec9-11e7-a4c3-e9873358b384</p>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3557847/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495293144 (ipmc11)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:20:09</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3557847%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495293144%20(ipmc11)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A20%3A09">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>
  </div>
</div>

	<h2>Error 403: Forbidden</h2>
	<p>You don't have permissions to access this page.
	This usually means one of the following:</p>
	<ul>
	<li>this file and directory permissions make them unavailable from the Internet.</li>
	<li>.htaccess contains instructions that prevent public access to this file or directory.</li>
	</ul>
	<p>Please check file and directory permissions and .htaccess configuration if you are able to do this.
	Otherwise, request your webmaster to grant you access.</p>

<head>
  <title>Pardon Our Interruption</title>

        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>www.apa.org</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running. Additional information is available in this <a title='Third party browser plugins that block javascript' href='http://ds.tl/help-third-party-plugins' target='_blank'>support article</a>.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>
          To request an unblock, please fill out the form below and we will review it as soon as possible.
        </p>

 <HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>403 Forbidden</TITLE>
<BASE href="/error_docs/"><!--[if lte IE 6]></BASE><![endif]-->
<script src="/cdn-cgi/apps/head/BtQrImfluwgkUBuTB053YoIqC84.js"></script></HEAD>
<BODY>
<H1>Forbidden</H1>
You do not have permission to access this document.
<P>
<HR>
<ADDRESS>
Web Server at le-gal.org
</ADDRESS>

<!--
   - Unfortunately, Microsoft has added a clever new
   - "feature" to Internet Explorer. If the text of
   - an error's message is "too small", specifically
   - less than 512 bytes, Internet Explorer returns
   - its own error message. You can turn that off,
   - but it's pretty tricky to find switch called
   - "smart error messages". That means, of course,
   - that short error messages are censored by default.
   - IIS always returns error messages that are long
   - enough to make Internet Explorer happy. The
   - workaround is pretty simple: pad the error
   - message with a big comment like this to push it
   - over the five hundred and twelve bytes minimum.
   - Of course, that's exactly what you're reading
   - right now.
   -->

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>

		<meta property="og:description" content="A Disease of Compulsive and Uncontrolled Drinking 

Alcoholism is widely recognized as a disease of compulsive drinking, which can be arrested, but not cured. It is a progressive illness, which will only get worse as long as the person continues to drink. Total abstinence from drinking is the only way to arrest this disease.

Alcoholism"/>

<section id="content" style="width: 100%;">
			<div id="post-1511" class="post-1511 page type-page status-publish has-post-thumbnail hentry">
			
			<span class="entry-title rich-snippet-hidden">
			What Is Alcoholism?		</span>
	
			<span class="vcard rich-snippet-hidden">
			<span class="fn">
				<a href="https://al-anon.org/blog/author/simeon/" title="Posts by Simeon" rel="author">Simeon</a>			</span>
		</span>
	
			<span class="updated rich-snippet-hidden">
			2017-10-02T09:27:49+00:00		</span>
	
																		<div class="fusion-flexslider flexslider post-slideshow">
							<ul class="slides">
																																																				<li>
										<a href="https://al-anon.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/is_for_you-1.jpg" data-rel="iLightbox[gallery1511]" title="" data-title="is_for_you" data-caption="">
											<img src="https://al-anon.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/is_for_you-1.jpg" alt="" role="presentation" />
										</a>
									</li>
																																																																																																																																																																											</ul>
						</div>
												
			<div class="post-content">
				<div  class="fusion-fullwidth fullwidth-box fusion-ie-mode nonhundred-percent-fullwidth"  style='background-color: rgba(255,255,255,0);background-position: left top;background-repeat: no-repeat;padding-top:20px;padding-right:0px;padding-bottom:20px;padding-left:0px;border-top-width:0px;border-bottom-width:0px;border-color:#eae9e9;border-top-style:solid;border-bottom-style:solid;'><div class="fusion-builder-row fusion-row "><div  class="fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_1_6  fusion-one-sixth fusion-column-first 1_6"  style='margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;width:13.3333%; margin-right: 4%;'>
					<div class="fusion-column-wrapper" style=""  data-bg-url="">
						<div class="fusion-clearfix"></div><div class="fusion-column-wrapper" style="content:'';z-index:-1;position:absolute;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;left:0;background-position:left top;background-repeat:no-repeat;-webkit-background-size:cover;-moz-background-size:cover;-o-background-size:cover;background-size:cover;"  data-bg-url=""></div>

					</div>
				</div><div  class="fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_2_3  fusion-two-third 2_3"  style='margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;width:65.3333%; margin-right: 4%;'>
					<div class="fusion-column-wrapper" style=""  data-bg-url="">
						<div class="fusion-title title fusion-sep-none fusion-title-center fusion-title-size-two" style="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:30px;"><h2 class="title-heading-center">A Disease of Compulsive and Uncontrolled Drinking</h2></div><p>Alcoholism is widely recognized as a disease of compulsive drinking, which can be arrested, but not cured. It is a progressive illness, which will only get worse as long as the person continues to drink. Total abstinence from drinking is the only way to arrest this disease.</p>
<p>Alcoholism affects the entire family; everyone who has contact with the alcoholic is affected. The only person who can stop the alcoholic from drinking is the alcoholic himself or herself.</p>
<div class="fusion-clearfix"></div><div class="fusion-column-wrapper" style="content:'';z-index:-1;position:absolute;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;left:0;background-position:left top;background-repeat:no-repeat;-webkit-background-size:cover;-moz-background-size:cover;-o-background-size:cover;background-size:cover;"  data-bg-url=""></div>

					</div>
				</div><div  class="fusion-layout-column fusion_builder_column fusion_builder_column_1_6  fusion-one-sixth fusion-column-last 1_6"  style='margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;width:13.3333%'>
					<div class="fusion-column-wrapper" style=""  data-bg-url="">
						<div class="fusion-clearfix"></div><div class="fusion-column-wrapper" style="content:'';z-index:-1;position:absolute;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;left:0;background-position:left top;background-repeat:no-repeat;-webkit-background-size:cover;-moz-background-size:cover;-o-background-size:cover;background-size:cover;"  data-bg-url=""></div>

					</div>
				</div></div></div>
							</div>
																					</div>
		</section>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2702242/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495384680 (ipmc11)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:22:00</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2702242%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495384680%20(ipmc11)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A22%3A00">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2686987/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495390938 (ipmc21)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:22:07</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2686987%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495390938%20(ipmc21)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A22%3A07">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>
  </div>
</div>

 <html><head><title>Error 406 - Not Acceptable</title><head><body><h1>Error 406 - Not Acceptable</h1><p>Generally a 406 error is caused because a request has been blocked by Mod Security. If you believe that your request has been blocked by mistake please contact the web site owner.</p></body></html>

 <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<html><head>
<title>403 Forbidden</title>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3347898/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495424034 (ipmc11)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:22:47</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3347898%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495424034%20(ipmc11)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A22%3A47">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>
  </div>

<span
class="bable">31&nbsp;Bible Verses about </span><h1>Parents Duty To Children</h1><div
class="no-w verse-cont block-verse"><h2>Most Relevant Verses</h2><div
class="content-box-wrapper-1 topic-cont-box"><div
class="ad_right" style="background-color: #ffffff">
 <script async src="//pagead2.googlesyndication.com/pagead/js/adsbygoogle.js"></script> 
<ins
class="adsbygoogle"
style="display:inline-block;width:300px;height:250px"
data-ad-client="ca-pub-7806653645243842"
data-ad-slot="5755393538"></ins> <script>(adsbygoogle=window.adsbygoogle||[]).push({});</script> </div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Titus/2/4">Titus 2:4</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Titus 2:4 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Wives">Wives</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Teaching-In-The-Church">Teaching In The Church</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Responsibility,-For-God~s-World">Responsibility, For God's World</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Young-Lovers">Young Lovers</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Bad-Parents">Bad Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Wives,-Duties-Of">Wives, Duties Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Young-Ladies">Young Ladies</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Affection,-Kinds-Of">Affection, Kinds Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Children,-Good-Parental-Examples">Children, Good Parental Examples</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Becoming-A-Parent">Becoming A Parent</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Children,-Parents-Love">Children, Parents Love</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Love-For-Children">Love For Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Children,-needs-of">Children, needs of</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
so that they may encourage the young women to love their husbands, to love their children,</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
class="ad_right"></div><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Matthew/19/13">Matthew 19:13-14</a>
</span><div></div><p>
Then some children were brought to Him so that He might lay His hands on them and pray; and the disciples rebuked them. But Jesus said, "Let the children alone, and do not hinder them from coming to Me; for the kingdom of heaven belongs to such as these."</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">

class="exdous">

<span

style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
Train up a child in the way he should go, Even when he is old he will not depart from it.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Ephesians/6/4">Ephesians 6:4</a>

<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Ephesians 6:4 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a

class="tags" href="/topics/Family,-Worship-In">Family, Worship In</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Abusive-Parents">Abusive Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Teachers">Teachers</a><a

class="tags" href="/topics/Child-Abuse">Child Abuse</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Instruction-Of-Children">Instruction Of Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Injustice,-Examples-Of">Injustice, Examples Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Being-A-Teacher">Being A Teacher</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Training-Children">Training Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Controlling-Parents">Controlling Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Responsibility,-For-God~s-World">Responsibility, For God's World</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Abuse-Of-Authority,-Warnings-Against">Abuse Of Authority, Warnings Against</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/evangelists,-identity-of">evangelists, identity of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Infants">Infants</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Anger-Of-Man,-Cause">Anger Of Man, Cause</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Love,-And-The-World">Love, And The World</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Education,-At-Home">Education, At Home</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Fathers,-Responsibilities-Of">Fathers, Responsibilities Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Rights">Rights</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
Fathers, do not provoke your children to anger, but bring them up in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Deuteronomy/4/9">Deuteronomy 4:9</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Deuteronomy 4:9 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Caring-For-Children">Caring For Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Baby-dedication">Baby dedication</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Caution">Caution</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Fathers,-Responsibilities-Of">Fathers, Responsibilities Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/discipline,-in-the-family">discipline, in the family</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Schools">Schools</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Learning-From-The-Past">Learning From The Past</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/diligence">diligence</a><a

"Only give heed to yourself and keep your soul diligently, so that you do not forget the things which your eyes have seen and they do not depart from your heart all the days of your life; but make them known to your sons and your grandsons.</p></div></div><div

class="tags" href="/topics/Correction">Correction</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Not-Dying">Not Dying</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Crimes">Crimes</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Admonition,-Of-Parents">Admonition, Of Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Authority-Within-The-Family,-Kinds-Of">Authority Within The Family, Kinds Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Fathers,-Responsibilities-Of">Fathers, Responsibilities Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Punishment">Punishment</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
Do not hold back discipline from the child, Although you strike him with the rod, he will not die.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Proverbs/29/17">Proverbs 29:17</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Proverbs 29:17 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Discipline">Discipline</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Baby-dedication">Baby dedication</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Bad-Parents">Bad Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Caring-For-Children">Caring For Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Children,-Should-Be-Treated">Children, Should Be Treated</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Becoming-A-Parent">Becoming A Parent</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Children,-Good-Kids">Children, Good Kids</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Being-A-Teacher">Being A Teacher</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Authority-Within-The-Family,-Kinds-Of">Authority Within The Family, Kinds Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/discipline,-in-the-family">discipline, in the family</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Bad-Children">Bad Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Sons">Sons</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Pleasing-Men">Pleasing Men</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Correction">Correction</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
Correct your son, and he will give you comfort; He will also delight your soul.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Hebrews/12/7">Hebrews 12:7</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Hebrews 12:7 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Enduring">Enduring</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Discipline">Discipline</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Fathers-And-Sons">Fathers And Sons</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Suffering,-Of-Believers">Suffering, Of Believers</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Training-Children">Training Children</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/discipline,-in-the-family">discipline, in the family</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Living-As-God~s-Children">Living As God's Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/discipline,-divine">discipline, divine</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Sons">Sons</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Suffering,-Hardship">Suffering, Hardship</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
It is for discipline that you endure; God deals with you as with sons; for what son is there whom his father does not discipline?</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Colossians/3/21">Colossians 3:21</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Colossians 3:21 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Strictness">Strictness</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Becoming-A-Parent">Becoming A Parent</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Bad-Parents">Bad Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Being-A-Dad">Being A Dad</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Caring-For-Children">Caring For Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/discouragement">discouragement</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Nurture">Nurture</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Fathers,-Responsibilities-Of">Fathers, Responsibilities Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/discipline,-in-the-family">discipline, in the family</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Belittling">Belittling</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Resentment,-Against-People">Resentment, Against People</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Abusive-Parents">Abusive Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Abuse-Of-Authority,-Warnings-Against">Abuse Of Authority, Warnings Against</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Provoking">Provoking</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Anger-Management">Anger Management</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Heads-Of-The-Family">Heads Of The Family</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Domestic-Violence">Domestic Violence</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Being-A-Parent">Being A Parent</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Child-Abuse">Child Abuse</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Love,-And-The-World">Love, And The World</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Instruction-Of-Children">Instruction Of Children</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
Fathers, do not exasperate your children, so that they will not lose heart.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Genesis/24/1">Genesis 24:1-4</a>
</span><div></div><p>
Now Abraham was old, advanced in age; and the LORD had blessed Abraham in every way. Abraham said to his servant, the oldest of his household, who had charge of all that he owned, "Please place your hand under my thigh, and I will make you swear by the LORD, the God of heaven and the God of earth, that you shall not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I live,											<a
href="javascript:void();" class="read-more-span"><i>read more.</i></a><br>
<span
class="read-more-span">but you will go to my country and to my relatives, and take a wife for my son Isaac."</span></p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Genesis/28/1">Genesis 28:1-2</a>
</span><div></div><p>
So Isaac called Jacob and blessed him and charged him, and said to him, "You shall not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan. "Arise, go to Paddan-aram, to the house of Bethuel your mother's father; and from there take to yourself a wife from the daughters of Laban your mother's brother.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Genesis/17/18">Genesis 17:18</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Genesis 17:18 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Bad-Parents">Bad Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Parents-Prayer-For-Their-Children">Parents Prayer For Their Children</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Intercessory-Prayer">Intercessory Prayer</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
And Abraham said to God, "Oh that Ishmael might live before You!"</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/1-Chronicles/29/19">1 Chronicles 29:19</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="1 Chronicles 29:19 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div

and give to my son Solomon a perfect heart to keep Your commandments, Your testimonies and Your statutes, and to do them all, and to build the temple, for which I have made provision."</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Job/1/5">Job 1:5</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="Job 1:5 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div
class="popup" ><div
class="arrow"></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Making-People-Holy">Making People Holy</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Cursing-God">Cursing God</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Bad-Parents">Bad Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Families,-Examples-Of">Families, Examples Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Worldly-Pleasures,-Leads-To">Worldly Pleasures, Leads To</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Custom">Custom</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Early-Rising">Early Rising</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Morning-Devotions">Morning Devotions</a></div><div><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Rising-Early">Rising Early</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Burnt-offering">Burnt offering</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Those-Who-Rose-Early">Those Who Rose Early</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Parents-Prayer-For-Their-Children">Parents Prayer For Their Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Order-In-The-Home">Order In The Home</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Rising-Early,-Examples-Of">Rising Early, Examples Of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Sons">Sons</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
When the days of feasting had completed their cycle, Job would send and consecrate them, rising up early in the morning and offering burnt offerings according to the number of them all; for Job said, "Perhaps my sons have sinned and cursed God in their hearts." Thus Job did continually.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/2-Samuel/12/16">2 Samuel 12:16</a>
</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div
class="concepts">
<a
title="2 Samuel 12:16 Verse Concepts" />Verse&nbsp;Concepts</a><div

class="tags" href="/topics/Parental-Love">Parental Love</a></div><div

David therefore inquired of God for the child; and David fasted and went and lay all night on the ground.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span

</span><div>

and implored Him earnestly, saying, "My little daughter is at the point of death; please come and lay Your hands on her, so that she will get well and live."</p></div></div><div

</span><div>

Therefore He came again to Cana of Galilee where He had made the water wine And there was a royal official whose son was sick at Capernaum.</p></div></div></div><div

class="tags" href="/topics/Respect,-For-Human-Beings">Respect, For Human Beings</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Parental-Discipline">Parental Discipline</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Family,-Worship-In">Family, Worship In</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Abusive-Parents">Abusive Parents</a><a

class="tags" href="/topics/Being-A-Teacher">Being A Teacher</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Family-Unity">Family Unity</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Admonition,-Of-Parents">Admonition, Of Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Childrearing">Childrearing</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Responsibility,-For-God~s-World">Responsibility, For God's World</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Abuse-Of-Authority,-Warnings-Against">Abuse Of Authority, Warnings Against</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Child-Abuse">Child Abuse</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Parents-Duty-To-Children">Parents Duty To Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Love,-And-The-World">Love, And The World</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Education,-At-Home">Education, At Home</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Training-Children">Training Children</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Controlling-Parents">Controlling Parents</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Rights">Rights</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Heads-Of-The-Family">Heads Of The Family</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/evangelists,-identity-of">evangelists, identity of</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Infants">Infants</a><a
class="tags" href="/topics/Anger-Of-Man,-Cause">Anger Of Man, Cause</a></div><div
style="clear: both;"></div></div></div></span></div><p>
Fathers, do not provoke your children to anger, but bring them up in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
class="ad_right"></div><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a

</span><div>
<span
