"These things I have spoken to you, so that in Me you may have peace In the world you have tribulation, but take courage; I have overcome the world."</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Psalm/127/3">Psalm 127:3-5</a>
</span><div></div><p>
Behold, children are a gift of the LORD, The fruit of the womb is a reward. Like arrows in the hand of a warrior, So are the children of one's youth. How blessed is the man whose quiver is full of them; They will not be ashamed When they speak with their enemies in the gate.</p></div></div><div

Train up a child in the way he should go, Even when he is old he will not depart from it.</p></div></div><div

</span><div>

Fathers, do not exasperate your children, so that they will not lose heart.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Proverbs/23/13">Proverbs 23:13-14</a>
</span><div></div><p>
Do not hold back discipline from the child, Although you strike him with the rod, he will not die. You shall strike him with the rod And rescue his soul from Sheol.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">
<a
href="/Proverbs/3/11">Proverbs 3:11-12</a>
</span><div></div><p>
My son, do not reject the discipline of the LORD Or loathe His reproof, For whom the LORD loves He reproves, Even as a father corrects the son in whom he delights.</p></div></div><div
class="content-box-1"><div
id="Replacep">
<span
class="exdous">

</span><div>
<span
class="verse"><div

Listen to your father who begot you, And do not despise your mother when she is old.</p></div></div></div><div

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 502 

 
DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 502 

 
DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>
DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 502

If you believe that your request has been blocked by mistake please contact the web site owner.</p></body></html>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4204396/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495467557 (ipmc21)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:23:40</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4204396%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495467557%20(ipmc21)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A23%3A40">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>
  </div>

<!--
   - Unfortunately, Microsoft has added a clever new
   - "feature" to Internet Explorer. If the text of
   - an error's message is "too small", specifically
   - less than 512 bytes, Internet Explorer returns
   - its own error message. You can turn that off,
   - but it's pretty tricky to find switch called
   - "smart error messages". That means, of course,
   - that short error messages are censored by default.
   - IIS always returns error messages that are long
   - enough to make Internet Explorer happy. The
   - workaround is pretty simple: pad the error
   - message with a big comment like this to push it
   - over the five hundred and twelve bytes minimum.
   - Of course, that's exactly what you're reading
   - right now.
   -->

<body class='block-page'>
  <div class='container'>
    <div class='row'>
      <div class='sidebar col-lg-4 col-sm-5'>
        <img src="//cdn.distilnetworks.com/images/anomaly-detected.png" alt="0">
      </div>
      <div class='content col-lg-8 col-sm-7'>
        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>psycnet.apa.org</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running. Additional information is available in this <a title='Third party browser plugins that block javascript' href='http://ds.tl/help-third-party-plugins' target='_blank'>support article</a>.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>
          To request an unblock, please fill out the form below and we will review it as soon as possible.
        </p>

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 406 

 <html><head><title>Error 406 - Not Acceptable</title><head><body><h1>Error 406 - Not Acceptable</h1><p>Generally a 406 error is caused because a request has been blocked by Mod Security. If you believe that your request has been blocked by mistake please contact the web site owner.</p></body></html>
DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>

    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>
DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>

If you believe that your request has been blocked by mistake please contact the web site owner.</p></body></html>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1447160/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495521438 (ipmc21)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:24:45</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC1447160%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495521438%20(ipmc21)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A24%3A45">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>

	<h2>Error 403: Forbidden</h2>

	<p>You don't have permissions to access this page.
	This usually means one of the following:</p>
	<ul>
	<li>this file and directory permissions make them unavailable from the Internet.</li>
	<li>.htaccess contains instructions that prevent public access to this file or directory.</li>
	</ul>
	<p>Please check file and directory permissions and .htaccess configuration if you are able to do this.
	Otherwise, request your webmaster to grant you access.</p>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4013093/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495531365 (ipmc11)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:24:57</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4013093%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495531365%20(ipmc11)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A24%3A57">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>

  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement('iframe'),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:false";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role="presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";

  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;

    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";

				<title>Strict evolutionary conservation followed rapid gene loss on human and rhesus Y chromosomes :  Nature :  Nature Research</title>

				function getRandomInt(min, max) {
					return Math.floor(Math.random() * (max - min + 1)) + min;
				}

				var oneOutOf = 10;

				if (getRandomInt(0, oneOutOf) === 0) {

											<meta name="keywords" content="Evolution, Genetics, Genomics" />
															<meta name="description" content="The human X and Y chromosomes evolved from an ordinary pair of autosomes during the past 200-300 million years. The human MSY (male-specific region of Y chromosome) retains only three percent of the ancestral autosomes/&#x27; genes owing to genetic decay. This evolutionary decay was driven by a series of five /`stratification/&#x27; events. Each event suppressed X-Y crossing over within a chromosome segment or /`stratum/&#x27;, incorporated that segment into the MSY and subjected its genes to the erosive forces that attend the absence of crossing over. The last of these events occurred 30 million years ago, 5 million years before the human and Old World monkey lineages diverged. Although speculation abounds regarding ongoing decay and looming extinction of the human Y chromosome, remarkably little is known about how many MSY genes were lost in the human lineage in the 25 million years that have followed its separation from the Old World monkey lineage. To investigate this question, we sequenced the MSY of the rhesus macaque, an Old World monkey, and compared it to the human MSY. We discovered that during the last 25 million years MSY gene loss in the human lineage was limited to the youngest stratum (stratum 5), which comprises three percent of the human MSY. In the older strata, which collectively comprise the bulk of the human MSY, gene loss evidently ceased more than 25 million years ago. Likewise, the rhesus MSY has not lost any older genes (from strata 1-4) during the past 25 million years, despite its major structural differences to the human MSY. The rhesus MSY is simpler, with few amplified gene families or palindromes that might enable intrachromosomal recombination and repair. We present an empirical reconstruction of human MSY evolution in which each stratum transitioned from rapid, exponential loss of ancestral genes to strict conservation through purifying selection." />

																																										<li class="parent parent-4"><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/index.html#lt">Letters</a></li>
																																																								<li class="current"><span>Article</span></li>
										</ul>
				</nav>
			</div>
			
								
										
					
	

									
										
					
	

	</div>

					</div></header>

			</div>

			<div id="constrain-content" class="cleared">

							<h1 class="article-heading">Strict evolutionary conservation followed rapid gene loss on human and rhesus Y chromosomes</h1>

	<h2 class="hidden">Article tools</h2>

		</header>


											
										
					

	
	
							
											 									

		
										
				
				
			
										
																													
			
								
			
								
												
																			
																									
																																							
																		
																		
																									
																																																					
																																																				
																																							
																									
																																							
																																
																																							
																		
																		
					
						
																
																																																		
				
				
				

			
																				
						
									<section><div class="section first no-nav no-title first-no-nav">

								<div class="content ">
					
					
					
												
										
					<div class="first-paragraph-abs" id="first-paragraph"><p>The human X and Y chromosomes evolved from an ordinary pair of autosomes during the past 200&#x02013;300 million years<sup><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref1" title="Charlesworth, B. The evolution of sex chromosomes. Science 251, 1030-1033 (1991)" id="ref-link-1">1</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref2" title="Lahn, B. T. &amp; Page, D. C. Four evolutionary strata on the human X chromosome. Science 286, 964-967 (1999)" id="ref-link-2">2</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref3" title="Ross, M. T. et al. The DNA sequence of the human X chromosome. Nature 434, 325-337 (2005)" id="ref-link-3">3</a></sup>. The human MSY (male-specific region of Y chromosome) retains only three percent of the ancestral autosomes&#x02019; genes owing to genetic decay<sup><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref4" title="Skaletsky, H. et al. The male-specific region of the human Y chromosome is a mosaic of discrete sequence classes. Nature 423, 825-837 (2003)" id="ref-link-4">4</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref5" title="Bellott, D. W. et al. Convergent evolution of chicken Z and human X chromosomes by expansion and gene acquisition. Nature 466, 612-616 (2010)" id="ref-link-5">5</a></sup>. This evolutionary decay was driven by a series of five &#x02018;stratification&#x02019; events. Each event suppressed X&#x02013;Y crossing over within a chromosome segment or &#x02018;stratum&#x02019;, incorporated that segment into the MSY and subjected its genes to the erosive forces that attend the absence of crossing over<sup><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref2" title="Lahn, B. T. &amp; Page, D. C. Four evolutionary strata on the human X chromosome. Science 286, 964-967 (1999)" id="ref-link-6">2</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref6" title="Charlesworth, B. &amp; Charlesworth, D. The degeneration of Y chromosomes. Phil. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. B 355, 1563-1572 (2000)" id="ref-link-7">6</a></sup>. The last of these events occurred 30 million years ago, 5 million years before the human and Old World monkey lineages diverged. Although speculation abounds regarding ongoing decay and looming extinction of the human Y chromosome<sup><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref7" title="Aitken, R. J. &amp; Marshall Graves, J. A. The future of sex. Nature 415, 963 (2002)" id="ref-link-8">7</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref8" title="Sykes, B. Adam&#x27;s Curse (Norton, W. W. &amp; Company, 2004)" id="ref-link-9">8</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref9" title="Graves, J. A., Koina, E. &amp; Sankovic, N. How the gene content of human sex chromosomes evolved. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 16, 219-224 (2006)" id="ref-link-10">9</a>, <a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/full/nature10843.html#ref10" title="Marshall Graves, J. A. Weird animal genomes and the evolution of vertebrate sex and sex chromosomes. Annu. Rev. Genet. 42, 565-586 (2008)" id="ref-link-11">10</a></sup>, remarkably little is known about how many MSY genes were lost in the human lineage in the 25 million years that have followed its separation from the Old World monkey lineage. To investigate this question, we sequenced the MSY of the rhesus macaque, an Old World monkey, and compared it to the human MSY. We discovered that during the last 25 million years MSY gene loss in the human lineage was limited to the youngest stratum (stratum 5), which comprises three percent of the human MSY. In the older strata, which collectively comprise the bulk of the human MSY, gene loss evidently ceased more than 25 million years ago. Likewise, the rhesus MSY has not lost any older genes (from strata 1&#x02013;4) during the past 25 million years, despite its major structural differences to the human MSY. The rhesus MSY is simpler, with few amplified gene families or palindromes that might enable intrachromosomal recombination and repair. We present an empirical reconstruction of human MSY evolution in which each stratum transitioned from rapid, exponential loss of ancestral genes to strict conservation through purifying selection.</p></div>


							
										
														
																																																													
															
					<div class="article-keywords inline-list cleared">
				<h2>Subject terms:</h2>
				<ul>
																														<li><a href="/nature/archive/subject.html?code=npg_subject_181%2Cnews_s22%2Cnews_s27">Evolution</a><span class="bullet">&bull;</span> </li><li><a href="/nature/archive/subject.html?code=npg_subject_208%2Cnpg_subject_212%2Cnews_s9">Genetics</a><span class="bullet">&bull;</span> </li><li class="last"><a href="/nature/archive/subject.html?code=npg_subject_208%2Cnpg_subject_212%2Cnews_s9">Genomics</a></li>				</ul>
			</div>
											
										
												
	
		<div class="figures-at-a-glance">

										
		<h1 class="at-a-glance-heading">At a glance</h1>

				
																				
		
		
		<div id="figure-browser-group" class="tab-group primary-tabs">
							<div class="tab-box active first" id="figure-figures">
					<h3 class="tab">Figures</h3>
					<div class="tab-content figure-browser" id="figure-browser-figures">
						<div class="tab-inner">
							<div class="item-index"><span class="item-count"></span>
																																</div>

														<ol style="width: 680px">
																																		
																		
																			<li>
																																	
											<figure>												<a class="item-link" href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/fig_tab/nature10843_F1.html">
													 													
	
																												
		
		
			
	<img src="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/carousel/nature10843-f1.2.jpg" alt="Comparison of rhesus, human and chimpanzee Y chromosomes." class="fig carousel-item" data-media-desc="Figure" data-media-id="figure" style="width:367px;height:200px;" />
												</a>

												<figcaption>
													<span class="legend cleared">
													Figure 1<span class="break">: </span><span class="figure-desc"><b>Comparison of rhesus, human and chimpanzee Y chromosomes.</b></span>
													</span>
													<div class="description">
													<p><b>a</b>, Schematic representations of rhesus, human and chimpanzee Y chromosomes, to scale. Other, single-copy, male-specific sequences that are neither X-degenerate nor X-transposed. <b>b</b>, Sizes (in Mb) of euchromatic sequence classes in MSYs. cen, centromere.</p>
													</div>

																									</figcaption>
											</figure>

										</li>
									 																										
																		
																			<li>
																																	
											<figure>												<a class="item-link" href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/fig_tab/nature10843_F2.html">
													 													
	
																												
		
		
			
	<img src="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/carousel/nature10843-f2.2.jpg" alt="Inventories of genes, both ancestral and added, in rhesus, human and chimpanzee MSYs." class="fig carousel-item" data-media-desc="Figure" data-media-id="figure" style="width:103px;height:200px;" />
												</a>

												<figcaption>
													<span class="legend cleared">
													Figure 2<span class="break">: </span><span class="figure-desc"><b>Inventories of genes, both ancestral and added, in rhesus, human and chimpanzee MSYs.</b></span>
													</span>
													<div class="description">
													<p>Ancestral genes grouped by stratum (1&#x02013;5). In rhesus, human and chimpanzee, current status of each MSY gene is indicated by shading in one of three columns: present and intact, inactivated pseudogene, or absent or deleted. Total numbers of intact genes, pseudogenes (pseudo), and absent genes&#x02014;both ancestral and added&#x02014;are tallied for each species. For each MSY gene, whether the most closely related human homologue is located on the X chromosome is shown (right).</p>
													</div>

																									</figcaption>
											</figure>

										</li>
									 																	
																		
									 																										
																		
																			<li>
																																	
											<figure>												<a class="item-link" href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/fig_tab/nature10843_F3.html">
													 													
	
																												
		
		
			
	<img src="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/carousel/nature10843-f3.2.jpg" alt="Kinetics of ancestral gene loss during evolution of five human MSY strata." class="fig carousel-item" data-media-desc="Figure" data-media-id="figure" style="width:149px;height:200px;" />
												</a>

												<figcaption>
													<span class="legend cleared">
													Figure 3<span class="break">: </span><span class="figure-desc"><b>Kinetics of ancestral gene loss during evolution of five human MSY strata.</b></span>
													</span>
													<div class="description">
													<p>Gene numbers are plotted on a log scale on the <i>y</i> axis, and time (in Myr before present) is plotted on the <i>x</i> axis. Filled circles show inferred or observed gene numbers in (from left to right) X&#x02013;Y ancestral chromosome (at time of stratum formation), rhesus&#x02013;chimpanzee&#x02013;human ancestral MSY (25 Myr ago), chimpanzee&#x02013;human ancestral MSY (6 Myr ago), and modern human MSY. Dotted and dashed lines represent best-fit curves to data points using each of three decay models as indicated.</p>
													</div>

																									</figcaption>
											</figure>

										</li>
									 								 							</ol>
						</div>
					</div>

	<div id="author-contributions">
		<h2 id="contrib-auth">Contributions</h2>
		<p>J.F.H., H.Sk., W.C.W., S.R., R.A.G., R.K.W. and D.C.P. planned the project. J.F.H., H.Sk., L.G.B., T.J.C. and N.K. performed BAC mapping, radiation hybrid mapping and real-time polymerase chain reaction analyses. T.G., R.S.F., S.D., Y.D., C.J.B., C.K., Q.W., H.Sh., M.H., D.V., L.V.N., A.C., L.C., J.V., H.K. and D.M.M. were responsible for BAC sequencing. J.F.H. and H.Sk. performed comparative sequence analyses. T.P. performed FISH analyses. J.F.H. and D.C.P. wrote the paper.</p>
	</div>

									<h1 class="section-heading toggle">Supplementary information</h1>
								<div class="content ">
					
																	<nav><ul class="section-nav inline-list cleared">

							
																																																																																																																																																																																																
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				<li class="#2 and 1 of 5"><a href="#accessions">Accession codes</a><span class="bullet">&bull;</span> </li> <li class="#3 and 2 of 5"><a href="#references">References</a><span class="bullet">&bull;</span> </li> <li class="#4 and 3 of 5"><a href="#author-information">Author information</a><span class="bullet">&bull;</span> </li> <li class="#5 and 4 of 5">Supplementary information<span class="bullet">&bull;</span> </li> <li class="#6 and 5 of 5"><a href="#comments">Comments</a></li>
						</ul></nav>

					
					
														
										
							
																				

<div class="box supp-info">
	
																
					
		<h2 class="pdf">PDF files</h2>
		<ol>
					<li><dl><dt><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/extref/nature10843-s1.pdf">Supplementary Information (16.3M)</a></dt><dd><p>This file contains Supplementary Notes 1-3, Supplementary Figures 1-16 with legends and Supplementary Tables 1-8.</p></dd></dl></li>
				</ol>
					
		<h2 class="text">Text files</h2>
		<ol>
					<li><dl><dt><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/extref/nature10843-s2.txt">Supplementary Data 1 (11.5M)</a></dt><dd><p>This is a FASTA file of rhesus MSY sequence assembly.</p></dd></dl></li>
					<li><dl><dt><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/extref/nature10843-s3.txt">Supplementary Data 2 (1.9K)</a></dt><dd><p>This file contains radiation hybrid mapping data vectors.</p></dd></dl></li>
					<li><dl><dt><a href="/nature/journal/v483/n7387/extref/nature10843-s4.txt">Supplementary Data 3 (9M)</a></dt><dd><p>This file shows the alignment of rhesus and human MSY sequences in FASTA format.</p></dd></dl></li>
				</ol>
	</div>	

									</div>

							</div></section>

							<dl>
								<dt>
																			<cite class="vcard"><span class="fn">0poponax 0poponax</span></cite> said:
																	</dt>
								<dd><p>This article appears to take no account of sequences for Orang Utang and Gorilla published by Underhill et al 1997 Genome Res. 7:996-1005; results that would justify substantively enhanced inferences</p></dd>
							</dl>
						</article>

					</li>
							</ol>
					
	<p class="comment-rss"><a href="/rss/feed?doi=10.1038/nature10843">Subscribe to comments</a></p>

		
				
	

									</div>

							</div></section>

		
		
		
									
										
					<section>
	<h1 class="hidden">Additional data</h1>
	<div class="additional-data hidden">
		
		

		
		
						
				
					
					
					
			</div>
</section>
	
																								
	</article>
</div>
<div id="extranav" role="complementary" class="col">
												
										
							
								



						
	
		

										
										
					

						

	


				
	<div class="box module" id="summary-box">
					<div id="edsumm" class="summary-item editors-summary" >
				<h2 class="sidebar-heading">Editor's summary
									</h2>
									<div class="full-snippet"><p>The mammal sex-determining X and Y chromosomes evolved from a pair of autosomes (&#x27;normal&#x27; non-sex chromosomes), but as a result of genetic decay, the male-specific region of the human Y chromosome retains only 3<span class="mb">&#x00025;</span> of the ancestral autosomal genes. Here, the authors have sequenced the corresponding region of the rhesus macaque Y, and reconstructed the trajectory of its evolution through an analysis of the rhesus, human and chimpanzee Y chromosomes. The results show that initial rapid loss of genes is followed by strict conservation through purifying selection. This runs counter to the view that the human Y chromosome is destined inevitably for extinction.</p></div>
							</div>
		
		
		
		
		
		
		
			</div>

													<noscript>
						
						
																		
						
						<a href="//pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/jump?iu=/285/nature.com/article&sz=300x250|300x100&t=pos%3Dright%26artid%3Dnature10843%26type%3Dlt%26issue%3D7387%26submeta%3Dnpg_subject_181%2Cnpg_subject_208%2Cnpg_subject_212%26abr%3D%21webtv&c=2571548699285889"><img src="//pubads.g.doubleclick.net/gampad/ad?iu=/285/nature.com/article&sz=300x250|300x100&t=pos%3Dright%26artid%3Dnature10843%26type%3Dlt%26issue%3D7387%26submeta%3Dnpg_subject_181%2Cnpg_subject_208%2Cnpg_subject_212%26abr%3D%21webtv&c=2571548699285889" alt="Advertisement" /></a>

      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>

        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>psycnet.apa.org</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running.         </ul>
        <p>
          To request an unblock, please fill out the form below and we will review it as soon as possible.
        </p>

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2072932/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495640445 (ipmc11)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:27:09</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2072932%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495640445%20(ipmc11)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A27%3A09">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>

            <div>
  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3828207/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495641315 (ipmc21)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:27:10</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3828207%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495641315%20(ipmc21)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A27%3A10">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>
  </div>
</div>

        <h1>Pardon Our Interruption...</h1>
        <p>
          As you were browsing <strong>www.apa.org</strong> something about your browser made us think you were a bot. There are a few reasons this might happen:
        </p>
        <ul>
          <li>You're a power user moving through this website with super-human speed.</li>
          <li>You've disabled JavaScript in your web browser.</li>
          <li>A third-party browser plugin, such as Ghostery or  NoScript, is preventing JavaScript from running. Additional information is available in this <a title='Third party browser plugins that block javascript' href='http://ds.tl/help-third-party-plugins' target='_blank'>support article</a>.</li>
        </ul>
        <p>
          To request an unblock, please fill out the form below and we will review it as soon as possible.

  <div class="pmc-page-banner whole_rhythm">
    <h1 class="banner-color1 banner-text banner-title">Page not available</h1>
  </div>
  <div class="main-exception-content">
    <p>
      <em>Your access to PubMed Central has been blocked because you are using an automated process to retrieve content from PMC, in violation of the terms of the PMC Copyright Notice.</em>
    </p>
    <div class="pmc-warning-box el-exception-box shadow whole_rhythm">
<div class="el-exception-reason"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Reason: </span>Automated retrieval by user agent "DataScope (v0.5.0); python-requests/2.18.4".</div>
<div class="el-exception-url"><span style="font-weight: bold;">URL: </span>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4418547/</div>
<div class="el-exception-id"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Message ID: </span>1495642577 (ipmc12)</div>
<div class="el-exception-time"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Time: </span>2017/10/11 17:27:11</div></div>
    <p>Use of PMC is free, but must comply with the terms of the <a href="/pmc/about/copyright/">Copyright Notice</a> on the PMC site. For additional information, or to request that your IP address be unblocked, <span class="el-contact-help">please send an <a href="mailto:pubmedcentral@nih.gov?subject=%5BPMC%20Exception%20Feedback%5D%3A%20Blocked%20request.%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.&amp;body=%3E%20%0A%3E%20Reason%3A%20Automated%20retrieval%20by%20user%20agent%20%22DataScope%20(v0.5.0)%3B%20python-requests%2F2.18.4%22.%0A%3E%20URL%3A%20https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4418547%2F%0A%3E%20Message%20ID%3A%201495642577%20(ipmc12)%0A%3E%20Time%3A%202017%2F10%2F11%2017%3A27%3A11">email to PMC</a>.</span> For requests to be unblocked, you <em>must</em> include all of the information in the box above in your message.</p>

<li id="menu-item-312" class="menu-item menu-item-type-taxonomy menu-item-object-category menu-item-312"><a href="http://cotjournal.com/category/1-1-repair/">1.1 Repair</a></li>
</ul></div>
			
		</div>

	</div><!-- #menu-secondary .menu-container -->

	
		
		
	
	<div id="sidebar-primary" class="sidebar">

				
		<section id="text-2" class="widget widget_text widget-widget_text">			<div class="textwidget"><b><i>Change Over Time</i></b> is a semiannual journal publishing original articles on the history, theory, and praxis of conservation and the built environment. Each issue is dedicated to a particular theme as a method to promote critical discourse on contemporary conservation issues from multiple perspectives both within the field and across disciplines. Themes are examined at all scales, from the global and regional to the microscopic and material.</div>
		</section>
		
	</div><!-- #sidebar-primary .aside -->

	
	
	</div>

		
	<div class="content-wrap">

		<div id="content">
	
			
		<div class="breadcrumb-trail breadcrumbs" itemprop="breadcrumb">
			<span class="trail-browse">Browse:</span> <span class="trail-begin"><a href="http://cotjournal.com" title="Change Over Time" rel="home">Home</a></span>
			 <span class="sep">&nbsp; / &nbsp;</span> <span class="trail-end">Call for Papers</span>
		</div>	
			<div class="hfeed">
	
					
						
							
						<div id="post-35" class="hentry page publish post-1 odd author-cotjournal">
	
								
							<h2 class="post-title entry-title"><a href="http://cotjournal.com/call-for-papers/" title="Call for Papers" rel="bookmark">Call for Papers</a></h2>
	
							<div class="entry-content">
								
								<p><b>LGBTQ Heritage| </b>Spring 2019</p>
<p>Guest Editor: Ken Lustbader</p>
<p>In spite of the immense historic and cultural contributions of LGBTQ Americans, the LGBTQ community at large is among the least represented in our national, state, and local designation programs. To date, only eleven of the more than 92,000 sites on the National Register of Historic Places have been listed for their primary association with LGBTQ history. This underrepresentation has prevented effective advocacy and educational opportunities, leaving potentially significant sites and histories unappreciated, uncelebrated, and potentially endangered.</p>
<p>Over the past five years there has been growing recognition of the importance of LGBTQ place-based history by cultural heritage professionals, historians, and advocates. Place-based heritage provides a unique opportunity to illustrate the richness of LGBTQ history and the communitys contributions to American culture. Examples include historic sites associated with arts and architecture, important social centers such as bars and LGBTQ organization locations, places related to oppression and protest, and residences of notable figures.</p>
<p>This issue, published in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall Uprising, will explore questions related to LGBTQ cultural heritage: What are the challenges in identifying an often invisible and, at times, transient and denied history? How can historians and preservationists ensure for diverse representation of LGBTQ communities? How does one address significance and architectural integrity when recognizing LGBTQ sites that are often architecturally undistinguished and frequently altered?</p>
<p>We welcome contributions from US and international contexts on a range of topics: researching and documenting LGBTQ place-based sites; exploring rural, urban, and suburban LGBTQ narratives; approaches for categorization of resource types and cultural significance; challenges related to official recognition of LGBTQ-related sites; and solutions for interpretation and educational opportunities.</p>
<p>Submissions may include case studies, theoretical explorations, evaluations of current practices, or presentations of arts- or web-based projects related to LGBTQ cultural heritage.</p>
<p>Abstracts of 200-300 words are due 5 January 2018. Authors will be notified of provisional paper acceptance by 19 January 2018. Final manuscript submissions will be due mid May 2018.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<hr align="left" size="1" width="100%" />
<p><strong>Submission</strong></p>
<p>Articles are generally restricted to 7,500 or fewer words (the approximate equivalent to thirty pages of double-spaced, twelve-point type) and may include up to ten images. See <a title="Author Guidelines" href="http://cotjournal.com/?page_id=34">author guidelines</a> for full details, or email Senior Associate Editor,Kecia Fongat cot@design.upenn.edu for further information.</p>
								
																
							</div><!-- .entry-content -->
	
							<div class="entry-meta"></div>
	
								
						</div><!-- .hentry -->
	
							
												
							
						
					
			</div><!-- .hfeed -->
	
				
		</div><!-- #content -->
	
		
				
				
								
				</div><!-- .content-wrap -->

				
		</div><!-- #main -->

		
		
	
	<div id="sidebar-subsidiary" class="sidebar">

		
		<section id="text-3" class="widget widget_text widget-widget_text">			<div class="textwidget"><p>To read full articles from each issue, visit <i>Change Over Time</i> on the <a href="http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/change_over_time/">Project Muse website</a>.</p>

<p><a href="http://www.upenn.edu/pennpress/">A University of Pennsylvania Press Journal.</a></p>

        <main class="layout-3col__left-content" role="main">
                    <nav class="breadcrumb" role="navigation"><h2 class="breadcrumb__title">You are here</h2><ol class="breadcrumb__list"><li class="breadcrumb__item"><a href="/">Home</a></li></ol></nav>            <a href="#skip-link"

                                  <h1>LGBTQ Family Law Guide</h1>
                                                                      


<article class="node node-legal-resource view-mode-full clearfix node-470111">

  
  <span class="print-link"></span><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Introduction</h2>
<p>This guide covers many family law topics with information specific to LGBTQ people and families. We also link to other helpful resources.</p>
<p><strong>Contents</strong></p>
<ol class="toc">
<li><a href="#marriage">Marriage, Domestic Partnerships, and Civil Unions</a></li>
<li><a href="#divorce">Divorce, Parentage, Property, and Spousal Support</a></li>
<li><a href="#adoption">Second Parent Adoption</a></li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><a name="marriage"></a></p>
<h2>What&rsquo;s the difference between marriage and domestic partnership in Maine?</h2>
<p>Maine started recognizing domestic partnership on July 30th, 2004. Now, people who want to have their relationship legally recognized can choose a domestic partnership or a marriage.</p>
<h3>What is a domestic partnership?</h3>
<p>A domestic partnership is an agreement between two unmarried adults. It is an agreement to live together, and to be responsible for each other.</p>
<p>There are two kinds of domestic partnership in Maine:</p>
<ul>
<li>Registered Domestic Partnership</li>
<li>Unregistered Domestic Partnership</li>
</ul>
<p>An unregistered domestic partnership doesn&rsquo;t have the same benefits as a registered partnership. This guide will focus on the benefits of <strong>registered domestic partnerships</strong>.</p>
<h4>What about civil unions?</h4>
<p>If you have a civil union and want to know what effect this will have in Maine, you should talk with a lawyer if you can. If there is a question about the date of your marriage because of a civil union, you should definitely try to talk with a lawyer.</p>
<p>Most states where civil unions were recognized have passed laws that automatically turn civil unions from those states into marriages. In other words, if you have a civil union in one of these states, it may have been automatically changed to a marriage. States that have these laws are:</p>
<ul>
<li>New Hampshire</li>
<li>Vermont</li>
<li>Rhode Island</li>
<li>Connecticut</li>
<li>Delaware</li>
</ul>
<p>You should check with those states for details about these laws.</p>
<p>Other states still recognize civil unions, and don&#39;t have laws to change civil unions into marriages. These states are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Colorado</li>
<li>Illinois</li>
<li>New Jersey</li>
<li>Hawaii</li>
</ul>
<p>If you have a civil union from one of these states, you should talk with a lawyer about how that union will be treated by the State of Maine.</p>
<h3>What are the benefits of a domestic partnership in Maine?</h3>
<p>There are seven legal protections for registered domestic partners in Maine:</p>
<ol>
<li>The right to inherit your partner&rsquo;s property.</li>
<li>The right to make funeral and burial arrangements for your partner.</li>
<li>The right to be guardian or conservator of your partner&rsquo;s property if they are incapacitated.</li>
<li>The right to visit your partner in the hospital.</li>
<li>The right for you and your children to get health insurance through your partner&rsquo;s job <strong>if they offer a domestic partner insurance policy</strong>.</li>
<li>The right to take up to ten weeks of unpaid leave to care for your partner or their children if they are seriously ill or dying.</li>
<li>The right to submit your partner&rsquo;s absentee ballot.</li>
</ol>
<h3>Who can become registered domestic partners?</h3>
<p>Two people can become domestic partners if they:</p>
<ol>
<li>Are adults (18 or older)</li>
<li>Are mentally able to make this decision</li>
<li>Aren&rsquo;t closely related to each other</li>
<li>Have been living together in Maine for at least 12 months; and</li>
<li>Aren&rsquo;t already married, in a civil union, or in a registered domestic partnership.</li>
</ol>
<h3>How do I register my domestic partnership?</h3>
<p><a href="http://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/public-health-systems/data-research/vital-records/order/domstcprtnrspge.html">Visit the Maine Domestic Partner Registry</a>. You&rsquo;ll need to fill out the form and have it notarized (sign it in front of a notary public). Then submit your form and the $50 processing fee to the Maine Office of Vital Records.</p>
<p>If you can&#39;t afford the fee, you may be able to have your fee waived. You should include a letter with your application explaining why you can&#39;t afford the fee. You can include information about your sources of income, dependents, and debts that you have. You should also mention if you are a person with a disability or if you get any public benefits. It is possible that the Office of Vital Records won&#39;t waive this fee, even if you can&#39;t afford it.</p>
<p>You can send in this form to:<br />
	Vital Records<br />
	11 State House Station<br />
	220 Capitol Street<br />
	Augusta, ME 04333-0011</p>
<h3>What are some benefits of marriage that a domestic partnership doesn&#39;t have?</h3>
<ol>
<li>Marriage is recognized in every state. It is also usually recognized in other countries. Your domestic partnership may not be recognized in another state or country.</li>
<li>Domestic partnership doesn&#39;t have all the same benefits as marriage in Maine. These may include:
<ul>
<li>Employment-related marital benefits (like health insurance);</li>
<li>Some federal government benefits, like tax breaks. But you may be able to get Social Security benefits as a domestic partner. See the <a href="http://www.glad.org/doma">GLAD website</a> for more information about Federal benefits like this.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>In most cases the law doesn&rsquo;t recognize domestic partnership as equal to marriage. For example, if you end your domestic partnership you won&rsquo;t be able to get spousal support or other financial benefits you might get through a divorce.</li>
</ol>
<h3>What are some benefits of domestic partnership that marriage doesn&#39;t have?</h3>
<ol>
<li>Domestic partnerships are easier to get and easier to end. Depending on your situation, you may want the benefits of a domestic partnership without all of the benefits and limitations of marriage.</li>
<li>In some situations, being in a registered domestic partnership may let you still be eligible for some public benefits but still give you legal protections. For example, your domestic partner may not be counted as part of your household for TANF eligibility.</li>
</ol>
<h3>How do I end a registered domestic partnership?</h3>
<p>There are three ways to end your domestic partnership:</p>
<ol>
<li>Your domestic partnership will <strong>automatically end if either partner gets married</strong>.</li>
<li><strong>You and your partner can agree to end the partnership.</strong>
<ul>
<li>To do this, fill out this form: <a href="http://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/public-health-systems/data-research/vital-records/documents/pdf-files/VS71.pdf">Form V71</a>.</li>
<li>You&#39;ll both need to sign it in front of a notary public, and send it to the address on the form.</li>
<li>There is a $50.00 fee to do this. If you can&#39;t afford the fee, you may be able to have your fee waived. You should include a letter with your application explaining why you can&#39;t afford the fee. You can include information about your sources of income, dependents, and debts that you have. You should also mention if you are a person with a disability or if receiving any public benefits. It is possible that the Office of Vital Records won&#39;t waive this fee, even if you can&#39;t afford it.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>One partner can file to end the partnership</strong>.
<ul>
<li>First, complete <a href="http://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/public-health-systems/data-research/vital-records/documents/pdf-files/VS72.pdf">Form V72</a>.</li>
<li>Then photocopy the first page of that form and serve the other partner with this copy. You can serve the other partner by delivering the copy to them, or a person living with them in person. If you have tried to do this a few times and it hasn&rsquo;t worked, you can serve them by mail. There are instructions about this, and other kinds of &quot;service&quot; on the form itself</li>
<li>If you still can&#39;t serve the other partner, you may be able to serve them by having a notice published in a newspaper, or some other way. If it gets to this, you may want to get help from a lawyer.</li>
<li>Once you have served your partner, you will file the original three-page form with the Maine Office of Vital Records, at the address on the form.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<p>You can learn more about this process on the <a href="http://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/public-health-systems/data-research/vital-records/order/domstcprtnrspge.html">State of Maine website</a>.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><a name="divorce"></a></p>
<h2>Same-Sex Divorce:&nbsp; Potential issues with parentage, spousal support, and marital property due to marriage date</h2>
<h3>Parentage</h3>
<p>You and/or your spouse may have parented children who are not your biological or adopted children during your relationship. You don&#39;t need to be married to ask the court to decide if you are a parent, or to decide on parental rights and responsibilities. On July 1, 2016, the Maine Parentage Act made the definition of a parent much broader. <a href="http://ptla.org/maine-parentage-act">Read about the Maine Parentage Act</a>.</p>
<h3>Marital Property</h3>
<p>When you are getting divorced, the Court has the power to fairly divide up the property from the marriage. &quot;Marital property&quot; is property (land, homes, cars, appliances, etc.) that either of you got during your marriage. Even if something is only in one of your names, it is still &quot;marital property&quot; if you got it while you were married.</p>
<p>Usually property you got before you were married, and gifts made just to you during the marriage aren&#39;t marital property. You can each claim your own &quot;non-marital&quot; property.</p>
<p>The divorce order must include how all of your &ldquo;marital property&rdquo; is going to be divided.</p>
<p>You may have committed to each other privately or through a domestic partnership or civil union before same-sex marriage was legal and then married later. <strong>One or both of you may want some of your non-marital property to be considered marital because of your earlier commitment. If this is an issue in your divorce or if you have pensions, retirement plans, or other property issues, try to get a lawyer.</strong></p>
<h3>Spousal Support</h3>
<p>When you are getting divorced, the Court may also order one spouse to pay the other spousal support. One main factor the Court considers in deciding whether a spouse should pay spousal support is the length of your marriage.</p>
<p>You may have committed to each other privately or through a domestic partnership or civil union before same-sex marriage was legal and then married later. One or both of you may want the Court to consider the date of your marriage as earlier than the date you were legally married. If this is an issue in your divorce, try to get a lawyer.</p>
<p><strong>For more detailed information about <a href="http://ptla.org/classroom/divorce-and-parental-rights-Maine">divorce with children</a>, or <a href="http://ptla.org/divorce-without-children-maine">divorce without children</a>, visit our interactive classrooms. </strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><a name="adoption"></a></p>
<h2>Second Parent Adoption</h2>
<p>When you marry or enter a partnership, you also gain a relationship with your partner or spouse&rsquo;s children. But you are not automatically a parent of these children. The Maine Parentage Act expanded the definition of parent, so that a wider range of parents are recognized. For example, a person who has acted as a parent for a long period of time, or intended parents using an egg or sperm donor, can be considered parents. This could protect you if you separate from your partner or spouse and want to continue a relationship with a child that is not your biological child. <strong>The safest way to protect your relationship with that child is to adopt them</strong>.</p>
<p>An adoption decree is a legal document that creates a parent-child relationship. Adoption has many benefits, like:</p>
<ul>
<li>Making both parents responsible for supporting the child.</li>
<li>Allowing the child to get benefits from a parent&rsquo;s Social Security, worker&rsquo;s compensation, or wrongful death.</li>
<li>Making the child eligible for health insurance through their parent&rsquo;s work.</li>
<li>Allowing a parent to make medical and school-based decisions for their child.</li>
</ul>
<p>An adopted child has all the rights that a biological child does.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3>I want a second parent adoption. What should I do?</h3>
<p>In Maine, unless there is a case about the child going on in District Court, you file for adoption in the Probate Court. Each county has its own Probate Court. <a href="http://ptla.org/maine-probate-courts">Find your local Probate Court</a>.</p>
<p>You should go to the Probate Court and ask for these forms (#1-7). You might also need to go to the District Court to ask for #8 and #9, if they apply to your case.</p>
<ol>
<li>Form A-1: Petition for Adoption and Change of Name.</li>
<li>Child&rsquo;s Birth Certificate. If you don&#39;t have the original, you can get a certified copy from <a href="http://www.maine.gov/dhhs/mecdc/public-health-systems/data-research/vital-records/order/birth1.html">Vital Records</a>. (If you can&#39;t afford the fee, you may be able to have your fee waived. You should include a letter with your application explaining why you can&#39;t afford the fee. You can include information about your income, dependents, and debts. You should also mention if you are a person with a disability or if you get any public benefits. It is possible that the Office of Vital Records won&#39;t waive this fee, even if you can&#39;t afford it.</li>
<li>Form A-4: Consent of Petitioning or Non-Petitioning Parent</li>
<li>Form A-7: Child Custody Affidavit</li>
<li>Form A-8: Confidential Statement To Accompany Petition for Adoption</li>
<li>Form A- 22: Acknowledgment Adoption Registry</li>
<li>VS9-R: State of Maine Certificate of Adoption</li>
<li>Any divorce decrees if the legal parent is divorced</li>
<li>Copies of any court orders that affected the custody of the child (Judgment of Parental Rights and Responsibilities, Adoption Decrees, Guardianship Orders, etc.)</li>
<li>Depending on your situation, there may be other forms you need to file.</li>
</ol>
<p>You should use the court&rsquo;s forms for this process. You can change them to say &ldquo;Adopting Parent&rdquo; instead of &ldquo;Mother/Father.&rdquo;</p>
<h3>What goes in the petition?</h3>
<p>You will need:</p>
<ol>
<li>Basic information (name, date of birth, address, etc.) of the people filing for adoption and the child;</li>
<li>Information about the child (birth name, other names, proposed new name);</li>
<li>Information about the legal custody of the child;</li>
<li>Names and addresses of all persons &ldquo;that affect the custody, visitation or access to the adoptee (the child)&rdquo;;</li>
<li>The relationship of the person filing the petition to the child;</li>
</ol>
<p>The current legal parent and the parent that wants to adopt should file for the adoption together. This is called &ldquo;petitioning.&rdquo; You will be called &ldquo;joint petitioners.&rdquo;</p>
<p>When there is more than one child, you will need to file for adoption of each child. These petitions can be consolidated (the court will hear them at the same time).</p>
<h3>How much will it cost?</h3>
<p>Each petition costs $65, and each child needs a separate petition. If you can&#39;t afford this fee, you can apply for a <a href="http://ptla.org/maine-court-fee-waivers#">fee waiver</a>. A finger print check (for the adopting parent) is $49. In York County, there is also a $10 fee.</p>
<p>If a Probate Court requires publication of a legal notice of the adoption to a specific person involved in the custody of the child, the cost could be $200 - $1,500, depending on the newspaper(s).</p>
<p>If a Probate Court requires a home study, (more on this below), fees will run from $1,200-$2,100. Home studies aren&#39;t usually done in second parent adoptions. If the judge wants to order one in your case and you can&#39;t afford it, you should tell the judge.&nbsp; They may be able to find a low-cost or free alternative.</p>
<p>You can ask the court to not do a home study in your case. This is called a &quot;waiver.&quot; To do this, you need to file a motion asking the judge to waive the home study.<span style="background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"> <a href="http://ptla.org/sample-motion-waive-adoption-home-study">Here&rsquo;s a sample motion</a>.</span></p>
<h3>What county do we file in?</h3>
<p>File in the county where the child lives or where the adoptive parent lives.</p>
<h3>What will the child have to do?</h3>
<p>If your child is 12 or older, the judge may talk with them about how they feel about the adoption. If the child is 14 or older, they have to sign a form agreeing to the adoption (Consent to Adoption - Form A- 6).</p>
<h3>If the child has another parent besides my partner or spouse, do they need to agree to the adoption?</h3>
<p>Yes. The law requires each of the child&rsquo;s living parents to agree to the adoption. To do this, any biological or adoptive parent must sign Form A-4 in front of a Probate Judge and any <a href="http://ptla.org/maine-parentage-act#de-facto-parent">de facto parent</a> must sign Form A-5 in front of a Probate Judge.</p>
<p>Where there is a known sperm or egg donor, that person may sign Form A-14 in front of a notary public and give up the right to know about the court case. In cases involving unknown sperm or egg donors, the doctor or sperm/egg bank can certify that the person filing the petition got the sperm/egg from a confidential source.</p>
<p>If a person who is a parent or is presumed to be a parent does not wish to give up their rights, then the only way to adopt the child is if that parent&rsquo;s rights are terminated in a separate court proceeding discussed here.</p>
<h3>Do we need to have a home study?</h3>
<p>Not usually. Home studies are meant for a situation when a child is leaving one family and being adopted into another. The home study makes sure that the home is right for the child. Home studies aren&rsquo;t usually ordered in cases involving step-parent or second parent adoptions because the child isn&rsquo;t leaving their home.</p>
<p>In many cases, the &ldquo;new&rdquo; parent is not a new partner, but someone who has already been parenting the child for some time. A lawyer can help prepare a document explaining your situation and make a motion to waive the home study.</p>
<p>If you can&rsquo;t afford a lawyer, you can write a letter to the court explaining your family&rsquo;s situation (for example, how long the child has lived with you, how long you and your partner have been together, etc.) and ask the court to waive the home study. <a href="http://ptla.org/sample-motion-waive-adoption-home-study">Here&rsquo;s a sample motion</a>.</p>
<h3>What happens if the court orders a home study?</h3>
<p>If the court orders a home study, you should tell the agency or social worker doing the study that the child and parents are already a family.</p>
<p>In some cases, the home study includes more than one visit to your home by a trained social worker from a licensed adoption agency or the Maine Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS). You and your child(ren) will also be interviewed. These are some of the things the social worker usually reports on:</p>
<ol>
<li>Why you want to be adopt;</li>
<li>A physical description of your home, play areas and safety features;</li>
<li>Background checks on the adopting parent(s);</li>
<li>The adoptive parents&rsquo; life experiences, family background, education;</li>
<li>Employment, relationship status and issues, and parenting experience;</li>
<li>Your current relationship and support systems, including how you communicate in your relationship and how you make parenting and financial decisions;</li>
<li>Your relationships with other children;</li>
<li>Your family&rsquo;s beliefs, values and practices; and</li>
<li>Your schedule and child care plans.</li>
</ol>
<p>They will also interview others close to your family. These are usually just references where people say supportive things about your family and the adoption. Once the information has been gathered and analyzed, the social worker then makes a recommendation on whether or not the Court should grant the adoption.</p>
<h3>Is there any alternative to a home study?</h3>
<p>Judges have to make sure that the adoption is in the child&rsquo;s best interests. Instead of a home study, the Probate Judge could appoint a guardian ad litem &ndash; usually an attorney &ndash; to look at the family&rsquo;s situation and make a report. This is a shorter process than the home study and can be paid for by the county where the petition is filed.</p>
<h3>What will the birth certificate look like? Will it say our child is adopted?</h3>
<p>Your child&rsquo;s birth certificate can look like any other birth certificate. On the Form VS-9, at line 21, just say that you don&#39;t want the birth certificate to reflect the adoption.</p>
<h3>What if we are already both listed as parents on the birth certificate?</h3>
<p>Even if you are both listed on the child&#39;s birth certificate, you still need to file a form VS-9 and pay the $60.00 fee at the time of the adoption.</p>
<h3>What is the adoption registry and how does it affect my family?</h3>
<p>The Maine Adoption Reunion Registry is a free service of the Maine Department of Health and Human Services. You don&#39;t have to register. This program is designed to reunite birth families and adoptees once the adoptee is 18 or older. At that time, if the adoptee and the biological family members both sign up with the Registry, a match will be made and information shared so that there can be a reunion. No match will be made without both the child and the biological parent or family signing up for the service.</p>
<hr />
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Thanks to GLAD for providing some of the basic content this piece is built on. Find more information on the GLAD website</em></p>
<p style="text-align: right;">Created 12/2016</p>
</div></div></div>

		<div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" id="content-journalnav"><div id="content"><h1 class="heading access-title">Access</h1><p class="login-txt"><strong>To read this story in full you will need to login or make a payment (see right).</strong></p><div id="breadcrumb"><div><a href="http://www.nature.com">nature.com</a><span class="divider"> &#x0003E; </span><a href="/nm/index.html">Journal home</a><span class="divider"> &#x0003E; </span><a href="/nm/journal/v15/n7/index.html">Table of Contents</a></div></div>
<h1 class="page-header">News</h1><hr class="separator" />
<p id="cite"><span class="journalname">Nature Medicine</span> <span class="b">15</span>, 716 - 717 (2009) <br /><span class="doi"><abbr title="Digital Object Identifier">doi</abbr>:10.1038/nm0709-716</span></p><p id="errorcor"></p>
<div class="tools"><ul class="toolsmenu xoxo"><li><h1 class="title">Article Tools</h1><ul class="links">
		
	
	
		
			

	
					








<li class="sendtofriend"><a href="/nm/foxtrot/svc/mailform?doi=10.1038/nm0709-716&amp;file=/nm/journal/v15/n7/full/nm0709-716.html" class="sendtofriend">Send to a friend</a></li>
<li class="export-citation"><a href="/nm/journal/v15/n7/ris/nm0709-716.ris" class="export">Export citation</a></li><li class="permissions"><a class="permissions" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=NPG&amp;publication=Nature Medicine&amp;title=Straight talk with... Mauro Ferrari&amp;author=					Jon Evans
	&amp;contentID=10.1038/nm0709-716&amp;publicationDate=07/01/2009&amp;volumeNum=15&amp;issueNum=7&amp;numPages=2&amp;pageNumbers=pp716-717">Rights and permissions</a></li
>



</ul></li></ul></div><div class="articleCol"><h2 id="atl"> Straight talk with... Mauro Ferrari</h2><p id="aug">Jon Evans<sup><a title="affiliated with " href="#a1">1</a></sup><div id="affiliations-notes">
			<ol class="decimal"><li id="a1">Chichester, UK</li></ol></div></p><p class="caff"/><hr class="separator" />
<div id="abs"><h3 class="hidden">Abstract</h3><p class="lead">Mauro Ferrari has Texas-size aspirations for using nanotechnology to treat illness. He teaches at both the University of Texas and Rice University &#x02014; and at the same time serves as president for the Alliance of NanoHealth, a Houston-based body for promoting nanomedicine.
<br />This past June, Ferrari also became professor and chairman of the newly established Department of Nanomedicine and Biomedical Engineering (nBME) at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston. With this new department, Ferrari aims to bring researchers from a wide range of medical and scientific disciplines together under one roof to develop new nanomedicines. The department will also train the next generation of medical students, allowing nanomedicine to become an integral part of the medical curriculum at the University of Texas.
<br />During a visit to the UK in June to speak at the launch of Swansea University's Centre for NanoHealth, touted as Europe's first center devoted to nanomedicine, Ferrari met with <b>Jon Evans</b> to discuss nanomedicine, the importance of matching technology to therapeutic need and becoming a medical student in his mid-40s.</p></div><hr class="separator" />

<p class="login-txt"><strong>To read this story in full you will need to login or make a payment (see right).</strong></p></div></div></div>

DEBUG in http: WebTextResource > 999 

 <html><head>
<script type="text/javascript">
window.onload = function() {
  // Parse the tracking code from cookies.
  var trk = "bf";
  var trkInfo = "bf";
  var cookies = document.cookie.split("; ");
  for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
    if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkCode=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trk = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
    else if ((cookies[i].indexOf("trkInfo=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 8)) {
      trkInfo = cookies[i].substring(8);
    }
  }

  if (window.location.protocol == "http:") {
    // If "sl" cookie is set, redirect to https.
    for (var i = 0; i < cookies.length; ++i) {
      if ((cookies[i].indexOf("sl=") == 0) && (cookies[i].length > 3)) {
        window.location.href = "https:" + window.location.href.substring(window.location.protocol.length);
        return;
      }
    }
  }

  // Get the new domain. For international domains such as
  // fr.linkedin.com, we convert it to www.linkedin.com
  var domain = "www.linkedin.com";
  if (domain != location.host) {
    var subdomainIndex = location.host.indexOf(".linkedin");
    if (subdomainIndex != -1) {
      domain = "www" + location.host.substring(subdomainIndex);
    }
  }

  window.location.href = "https://" + domain + "/authwall?trk=" + trk + "&trkInfo=" + trkInfo +
      "&originalReferer=" + document.referrer.substr(0, 200) +
      "&sessionRedirect=" + encodeURIComponent(window.location.href);
}
</script>
</head></html>
